props.text: Instructions: Answer all questions in the spaces provided. Show your working for calculation questions. You may use scrap paper for rough work.

props.heading: Section A: Number and Place Value

props.questionContent: What is the value of the digit 7 in the number 4,738? (1 mark)
Write the number five thousand, two hundred and sixteen in numerals. (1 mark)
Round 3,847 to the nearest hundred. (1 mark)
Which number comes exactly halfway between 2,400 and 2,600? (1 mark)
Calculate: 3,456 + 2,789 = _____ (Show your working) (2 marks)
Calculate: 5,003 - 1,847 = _____ (Show your working) (2 marks)
Sarah had $4,250 in her savings account. She withdrew $1,685 to buy a computer. How much money does she have left? (2 marks)
A library had 2,348 books. They received donations of 876 books and 1,254 books. How many books does the library have now? (2 marks)
Solve these multiplication problems: (4 marks - 1 mark each)
Solve these division problems: (4 marks - 1 mark each)
A bakery makes 8 trays of muffins each day. Each tray holds 12 muffins. How many muffins does the bakery make in one day? (2 marks)
There are 84 students going on a school excursion. If each bus holds 7 students, how many buses are needed? (2 marks)
Which fraction is equivalent to one-half? (1 mark)
Which fraction is greater: 2/3 or 3/4? (1 mark)
A chocolate bar has 12 pieces. Emma ate 1/4 of the chocolate bar. How many pieces did she eat? (2 marks)
Write the mixed number for: 2 wholes and 3/5. (1 mark)
How many millilitres are in 3 litres? (1 mark)
Convert 4 kilograms and 250 grams to grams. _____ g (1 mark)
A rectangle has a length of 12 cm and a width of 7 cm. What is its perimeter? (2 marks)
A movie started at 2:45 pm and finished at 4:20 pm. How long was the movie? (2 marks)
Tom bought a toy for $12.75 and paid with a $20 note. How much change did he receive? (2 marks)
Lucy is saving for a $45 game. She has saved $18.50 so far. How much more does she need to save? (2 marks)
Which amount is closest to $50? (1 mark)
How many sides does a hexagon have? (1 mark)
Which of these angles is greater than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees? (1 mark)
Name a 3D shape that has 6 square faces. (1 mark)

props.text: The table below shows the favourite fruits of students in Year 3:

props.html:
FruitNumber of Students
Apples12
Bananas8
Oranges15
Grapes5

props.questionContent: How many more students chose oranges than bananas? (1 mark)
What is the total number of students surveyed? (1 mark)
Which fruit was the least popular? (1 mark)
If you spin a spinner with 4 equal sections coloured red, blue, green and yellow, what is the chance of landing on blue? Write your answer as a fraction. (1 mark)
Complete the pattern: 5, 10, 15, 20, _____, _____, _____ (1 mark)
What is the rule for this pattern: 3, 7, 11, 15, 19? (1 mark)
If ◼ + 8 = 23, what number does ◼ represent? (1 mark)

props.heading: Parent Information: Understanding Your Child's Results

props.text: This assessment comprehensively evaluates your child's mathematical understanding across all key areas of the Year 3 Australian Curriculum. The total possible score is 50 marks. Below you will find detailed information about how your child's performance compares to Year 3 students nationally.

props.children: The following bands indicate where your child sits relative to Year 3 students across Australia:

items: 45-50 marks (90-100%): EXCEPTIONAL - Top 10% of Year 3 students. Your child demonstrates advanced mathematical thinking well beyond year level expectations. They show mastery across all domains and are ready for extension work.

40-44 marks (80-89%): EXCELLENT - Top 25% of Year 3 students. Your child has a strong grasp of Year 3 concepts and consistently applies mathematical reasoning. They are performing above the expected standard.
33-39 marks (66-79%): PROFICIENT - Top 50% of Year 3 students. Your child demonstrates solid understanding of Year 3 mathematics and is working at the expected standard for their year level.

25-32 marks (50-65%): DEVELOPING - Middle 50% of Year 3 students. Your child shows developing understanding but needs support in some areas to reach the expected standard. Targeted practice will help consolidate skills.

18-24 marks (36-49%): EMERGING - Bottom 30% of Year 3 students. Your child is working towards the expected standard and requires significant support to build foundational skills across multiple areas.

0-17 marks (0-35%): BEGINNING - Bottom 10% of Year 3 students. Your child needs intensive support and intervention to develop essential Year 3 mathematical concepts. Additional one-on-one assistance is strongly recommended.

props.text: Understanding performance by mathematical strand helps identify specific strengths and areas for growth:

props.title: Number and Place Value (Questions 1-4, 4 marks total)

props.children: This section assesses understanding of four and five-digit numbers, place value, rounding, and number ordering.

items: 4 marks (100%): Exceptional - Top 15% nationally. Strong place value understanding.
3 marks (75%): Proficient - Top 40% nationally. Solid grasp of concepts.
2 marks (50%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Basic understanding present.
0-1 marks (0-25%): Needs support - Bottom 30% nationally. Requires place value intervention.

props.children: This section evaluates computational fluency with four-digit addition and subtraction, including problem-solving applications.

items: 7-8 marks (88-100%): Exceptional - Top 12% nationally. Highly accurate with efficient strategies.
6 marks (75%): Proficient - Top 35% nationally. Generally accurate with minor errors.
4-5 marks (50-63%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Developing accuracy and strategies.
0-3 marks (0-38%): Needs support - Bottom 35% nationally. Requires basic operation support.

props.children: This section tests multiplication and division fact fluency up to 10 × 10, and application in word problems.

items: 11-12 marks (92-100%): Exceptional - Top 10% nationally. Excellent recall and application.
9-10 marks (75-83%): Proficient - Top 30% nationally. Good fact knowledge and problem-solving.
6-8 marks (50-67%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Developing fluency with facts.
0-5 marks (0-42%): Needs support - Bottom 40% nationally. Requires times tables practice.

props.children: This section assesses understanding of unit fractions, equivalent fractions, comparing fractions, and mixed numbers.

items: 5 marks (100%): Exceptional - Top 15% nationally. Strong conceptual understanding of fractions.
4 marks (80%): Proficient - Top 35% nationally. Good fraction sense and comparison skills.
3 marks (60%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Basic fraction concepts understood.
0-2 marks (0-40%): Needs support - Bottom 40% nationally. Needs fraction concept building.

props.children: This section evaluates understanding of metric units, conversions, perimeter, and time calculations.

items: 6 marks (100%): Exceptional - Top 12% nationally. Excellent measurement sense and conversions.
5 marks (83%): Proficient - Top 32% nationally. Strong understanding of measurement concepts.
3-4 marks (50-67%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Developing measurement skills.
0-2 marks (0-33%): Needs support - Bottom 35% nationally. Requires measurement practice.

props.children: This section assesses financial mathematics including change calculations, savings problems, and estimation.

items: 5 marks (100%): Exceptional - Top 18% nationally. Confident with money calculations.
4 marks (80%): Proficient - Top 40% nationally. Accurate money problem-solving.
3 marks (60%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Basic money concepts understood.
0-2 marks (0-40%): Needs support - Bottom 35% nationally. Needs real-world money practice.

props.children: This section tests knowledge of 2D and 3D shapes, angles, and geometric properties.

items: 3 marks (100%): Exceptional - Top 20% nationally. Strong geometric knowledge.
2 marks (67%): Proficient - Top 45% nationally. Good shape understanding.
1 mark (33%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Basic shapes recognised.
0 marks (0%): Needs support - Bottom 30% nationally. Requires shape exploration.

props.children: This section assesses data interpretation from tables and basic probability concepts.

items: 4 marks (100%): Exceptional - Top 15% nationally. Excellent data analysis skills.
3 marks (75%): Proficient - Top 38% nationally. Good interpretation abilities.
2 marks (50%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Developing data skills.
0-1 marks (0-25%): Needs support - Bottom 35% nationally. Needs data practice.

props.children: This section evaluates pattern recognition, rule identification, and early algebraic thinking.

items: 3 marks (100%): Exceptional - Top 18% nationally. Strong pattern and algebraic reasoning.
2 marks (67%): Proficient - Top 42% nationally. Good pattern recognition.
1 mark (33%): Developing - Middle 50% nationally. Basic patterns understood.
0 marks (0%): Needs support - Bottom 30% nationally. Needs pattern work.

props.text: The percentile rankings provided above are based on national NAPLAN data, research from the Australian Curriculum Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA), and typical Year 3 achievement standards across Australian schools. These benchmarks help you understand not just what your child scored, but where they stand compared to their peers nationally.

items: Strand-Specific Performance: Your child may excel in some areas while needing support in others. This is completely normal. Look at individual strand results to identify where to focus practice.

Working Towards Mastery: Year 3 is a critical year for building mathematical foundations. Students working at the 'Developing' level are making progress but need consistent practice to reach proficiency.
Growth Over Time: A single assessment provides a snapshot. Monitor progress over multiple assessments to see growth trends. Improvement in specific strands indicates effective learning.

Times Tables Matter: Strong performance in multiplication and division often correlates with overall mathematical success. Daily practice of times tables (5-10 minutes) significantly improves confidence.
Problem-Solving Skills: Questions requiring multi-step thinking (word problems) are more challenging. Students scoring well on these demonstrate advanced mathematical reasoning.

When to Seek Support: If your child scores in the 'Beginning' or 'Emerging' bands overall, or consistently struggles in 2-3 specific strands, consider additional tutoring or discussing support strategies with their teacher.

props.children: Your child is performing exceptionally well and is ready for enrichment:

items: Introduce Year 4 concepts to maintain engagement and challenge
Focus on open-ended problem-solving and mathematical investigations
Explore real-world applications of mathematics (budgeting, measurement projects, data collection)
Consider extension programs or mathematics competitions (ICAS, AMT)
Encourage explaining mathematical thinking to build deeper understanding

props.children: Your child is working at the expected standard and should focus on consolidation:

items: Continue regular practice to maintain skills and build confidence
Focus extra attention on any strands where they scored below 60%
Use online resources (Mathletics, Essential Assessment) for varied practice
Apply mathematics in daily life (cooking measurements, shopping calculations, time management)
Build mental computation strategies to improve speed and accuracy

props.children: Your child needs targeted support to reach the expected standard:

items: Focus on 2-3 priority strands where scores were lowest
Practice times tables daily using games, songs, or apps (multiplication is foundational)
Use concrete materials (blocks, counters, money) to build conceptual understanding
Break practice into short, frequent sessions (15 minutes daily is better than one long session)
Communicate with the teacher about specific areas needing support
Consider engaging a tutor for personalised instruction in weak areas

props.children: Your child requires significant support and intervention:

items: Urgent: Schedule a meeting with your child's teacher to develop an intervention plan
Consider professional tutoring focused on foundational skills (2-3 sessions per week)
Start with concrete, hands-on activities before moving to abstract concepts
Build number sense through counting games, number lines, and visual models
Focus initially on place value and basic operations before moving to complex topics
Celebrate small wins to build mathematical confidence and reduce anxiety
Investigate whether underlying issues (working memory, processing speed, maths anxiety) may need addressing

props.text: The Australian Curriculum defines clear achievement standards for Year 3 mathematics. By the end of Year 3, students are expected to:

keyTakeaways: Count and order numbers up to 10,000 and represent them in various ways
Recall addition and subtraction facts for numbers up to 20
Recall multiplication facts up to 10 × 10 and related division facts
Model and represent unit fractions and compare common fractions
Measure and compare lengths, masses, capacities using metric units
Tell time accurately and calculate time durations
Identify angles and classify shapes by their properties
Collect, represent, and interpret data using tables and graphs
Create and continue patterns and describe their rules

props.text: Students scoring 33 marks or above (66%) are demonstrating achievement at or above the expected Year 3 standard. Students scoring below this threshold are working towards the standard and require additional support.
Based on your child's results, create a personalised action plan:

items: Step 1: Identify the 2-3 strands where your child scored lowest (check strand analysis above)
Step 2: Set specific, achievable goals (e.g., 'Master 7, 8, and 9 times tables by end of term')
Step 3: Create a daily practice routine (consistency matters more than duration)
Step 4: Use a variety of resources (worksheets, online games, real-world activities)
Step 5: Track progress with weekly mini-quizzes or practice tests
Step 6: Celebrate improvements and maintain a positive attitude towards mathematics
Step 7: Communicate regularly with the teacher about progress and challenges
Online Platforms: Mathletics, Prodigy Math, Khan Academy Kids, Mathseeds
Times Tables Practice: Times Tables Rock Stars, Squeebles Times Tables, multiplication.com
Australian Curriculum Resources: Scootle (free educational resources), ABC Education
Workbooks: Oxford University Press Year 3 Maths, Pascal Press Australian Curriculum series
Games: Card games (multiplication war), board games (Yahtzee for addition), dice games
Apps: Motion Math, DragonBox Numbers, Todo Math, SplashLearn

props.text: Remember: Every child develops at their own pace. This assessment provides valuable information about current performance, but it does not define your child's potential or future success in mathematics. With appropriate support, practice, and encouragement, all students can improve their mathematical skills and confidence.

If you have concerns about your child's results or need guidance on how to support their learning, please don't hesitate to contact their teacher or consider engaging a qualified mathematics tutor who can provide personalised support.
